awd_titl_txt: Superbursts: Multi-dimensional Simulations of Deep Carbon Explosions on Neutron Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
Neutron stars (NS) are the densest objects in the universe, other than black holes, and have fascinated theorists and observers since they were first conjectured. Despite a wealth of observations across the electromagnetic spectrum over the last four decades, much of what happens in the deep interior of NS remains inscrutable. Knowledge of neutron star physics is growing rapidly, due to X-ray telescopes in space, laboratory nuclear experiments, and gravitational wave detectors such as the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO).  A research group at Michigan State University will help astronomers to better understand neutron stars by modeling the thermally unstable ignition of carbon on the NS surface and the resulting explosion (a "superburst") using a state-of-the-art multidimensional hydrodynamics computer code.  The models can reveal conditions in the outer layer of neutron stars, and help answer some critical science questions identified in National Academy reports: what is the nature of matter at exceedingly high density and temperature?, and what controls the mass, radius, and spin of compact stellar remnants?  The planned work includes activities to recruit the next generation of scientists and to inform the public, who ultimately support the scientific endeavor.  The group will develop educational resources to make it easier to use open-source computer simulations to explore stellar physics and incorporate discoveries made during the award into public talks at Michigan State's Abrams Planetarium.

Neutron stars are unique natural laboratories to study quantum chromodynamics at finite density and low temperature.  A number of recent observational, theoretical, and experimental developments have raised new questions about the internal constitution of neutron stars. For low-mass X-ray binaries, in which the neutron star accretes hydrogen- or helium-rich material, X-ray observations of accretion-induced phenomena over timescales ranging from seconds to decades provide important information about different layers of the neutron star. During accretion, runaway thermonuclear burning of the accreted material is observable as a Type I X-ray burst. The thousands of X-ray bursts and the rarer and more energetic superbursts encode information about the physics of dense matter and the workings of the accretion disk and boundary layer.   The researchers will use ignition models that account for relevant heating and cooling processes in the neutron star crust. The simulations will yield testable predictions for both the precursor burst observed from some sources and the evolution of luminosity with time during the superburst. The models will inform astronomers about conditions in the outer layer of neutron stars, and may give information about the explosion's effect on the accretion flow and the nature of nuclear flames in dense matter.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Neutron stars are unique natural laboratories to study matter at densities exceeding that of an atomic nucleus. Our understanding of these dense stars has been driven by X-ray and gamma-ray observatories; by detections of gravitational waves from merging neutron stars; and by ground-breaking experimental nuclear physics experiments and theoretical studies. Many neutron stars accrete hydrogen- and helium-rich material from a companion star. This accretion induces a number of observable, nuclear-powered phenomena over timescales of seconds to decades that provides important clues about the neutron star's interior.

This project studied superbursts?hours-long explosions occurring in a layer of carbon that accumulates from the fusion of accreted hydrogen and helium that recur roughly yearly. Superbursts are good probes of the outer layer, or crust, of the neutron star: they occur deep enough that they are sensitive to the temperature of the deep crust; in addition, they inform us about the nuclear burning in more shallow layers, which produces the carbon that ultimately fuels the superbursts. In addition, the superbursts ignite at densities similar to those in the center of massive white dwarf stars; for the white dwarfs, the unstable ignition of carbon is thought to lead to Type Ia supernovae, which which forge roughly half of the iron in our hemoglobin and are used by astronomers to measure the expansion of the universe.

Over the course of this project, the research team used the open-source stellar evolution code MESA to map out the transition between thermally stable and unstable carbon burning, for different concentrations of carbon, mass accretion rates, and heating from deeper layers of the neutron star crust. The temperature profiles at the point of ignition were mapped into a two-dimensional grid for studies of the onset of dynamical fluid motions during the explosion. Although we were only able to begin exploratory studies of the ignition, our one-dimensional models are useful for constraining the ambient conditions in the neutron star crust and may lead to constraints on the fusion cross-section for carbon.

This project provided research and professional training for a Michigan State University graduate student and two undergraduates. This training covers a broad set of skills including numerical computation, nuclear physics, astrophysics, and high-energy astronomy. This skill set is adaptable, flexible, and fits a wide range of science and technology careers in both the private and public sectors.  The undergraduate supported by this award assisted the PI with development of open-source notes on stellar evolution that incorporate exercises using the modern stellar evolution code MESA. These notes and exercises are used in several graduate courses, both at MSU and other institutions and therefore enhance the education infrastructure. A set of notes aimed at undergraduates were also prepared and made open-source. These notes also include numerical exercises, many inspired by the research in this project. These have been used in several editions of the undergraduate stellar physics course (over 100 undergraduate astronomy and physics majors) at Michigan State.
